document.docAuthor: Taylor, Nigel P., Zappi, Daniela C. & Albuquerque-Lima, Sinzinando
document.masterDocTitle: A new Pereskia (Cactaceae) from Minas Gerais, Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new Pereskia (Cactaceae) from Minas Gerais, Brazil

mods:name.mods:affiliation: University of Gibraltar, Gibraltar Botanic Gardens campus, ‘ The Alameda’, Red Sands Road, PO Box 843, Gibraltar GX 11 1 AA. nigelcactus. taylor @ gmail. com; http: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 8162 - 0505
University of Brasília, Secretaria da Coordenação de Pós-Graduação em Botânica - Caixa Postal 04457, Brasília DF, Brazil, CEP 70919 - 970. & Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Belém, PA, Brazil.
Laboratório de Biologia Floral e Reprodutiva, Centro de Biociências, Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Avenida Professor Moraes Rego 1235, Cidade Universitária, Recife, PE, 50670 - 901, Brazil.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type ( lectotype , designated by Leuenberger 1986: 119 ):—
Brazil , Bahia , ‘ Calderão’ [most likely Riacho Caldeirão, Mun. Maracás],
Oct. 1906
, Ule 7050 ( HBG !; isolectotype L )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Pereskia bahiensis subsp. minensis
(all from population vouchered as Zappi et al. 5106, except A). A, erect shrub habit ( Zappi et al . 5103), plant bearing a termite nest. B, habit showing long erect extension shoot (arrowed). C & D, arched apex of extension shoot bearing numerous parallel flowering branches. E, young spines. F & G, areoles bearing brachyblast leaves. Photos by Albuquerque- Lima.

FIGURE 2.
Pereskia bahiensis subsp. minensis
(all from Zappi et al. 5106, holotype plant, except B & G). A, flower-buds showing outer pericarpel bracts. B, flower-bud with outer pericarpel bracts and numerous adpressed inner scale-like bracts. C, flower half-open after 12 noon. D, inflorescence with flower, young fruit and buds. E & F, flowers with Halictid and honey bee visitors, respectively. G, young fruit (Zappi et al. 5103). Photos by Albuquerque-Lima.

FIGURE 3. Comparison of flowers and fruit of
Pereskia bahiensis subsp. minensis
(A, C, E, from Zappi et al. 5106) and
P. bahiensis subsp. bahiensis
(B, D, F, from Bahia, Mun. Brumado, north of Cristalândia, photographed 26 Jan. 2021). Scale marker for A & B = 1 cm. Photos by Albuquerque-Lima.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description:— Shrub to small tree, 1–6(–10) m, forming a trunk to 33 cm diam., main shoots erect to arching, stout. Areoles rounded, cushion-like, initially 3–6(–8) mm diam., later to 20 mm diam., producing straight spines, and 1–4 brachyblast leaves. Spines 0–6 on twigs, fasciculate to spreading, 2–5 cm , increasing in number and size on older branches. Leaves elliptic or obovate, often narrowly obovate on main shoots, flat or folded upward and recurved, (4–)5–12 × 2–7 cm , petiole short to indistinct, base of lamina attenuate, apex rounded to broadly acute, lateral veins (3–)4–7(–8). Inflorescence terminal, cymose-paniculate, by proliferation from the receptacles, 2–12-flowered, dense to lax, or flowers sometimes solitary. Flower perigynous, 4–7 cm diam., rose-like, showy; pedicel 1 cm , stout; receptacle turbinate, with prominent podaria and 3–8 areoles mainly on the upper half; bracts sepal-like, fleshy, outer bracts 4–6, spreading, inner bracts 4–6, erect, green with purplish to nearly black margin, keeled; outer perianth-segments 2–5, asymmetric, greenish red to reddish purple, inner segments 7–10, 20– 30 mm , emarginate, deep magenta-pink; stamens 5–10 mm , loosely clustered around the style, filaments white; ovary half-inferior to inferior, with distinct septal ridges at the roof; style 7–15 mm , cylindric, stigma-lobes 5–10, suberect. Infructescences lax, forming a cymose-paniculate cluster of up to 12 fruits, often pendent, or fruit solitary; 3–6 × 3–5 cm , pyriform or turbinate, angular-tuberculate, green to yellow when ripe and scented like pineapple, bracts usually deciduous. Seeds to 30 or more, obovate, 3.8–5.5 × 2.8–3.5 mm , laterally compressed.

Habitat and distribution: —Central-southern to northern Bahia ,
where it occurs in dry forest ( caatinga ) vegetation surrounding the Chapada Diamantina , planalto de Maracás ,
300–1070 m asl
. Endemic to Bahia
.

Conservation assessment :—Least Concern (LC) ( Taylor & Zappi, 2004: 171 ). This species has been taken into cultivation as a hedge plant in the region where is native, ensuring its survival even in disturbed areas.
